Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant: Developing a National Higher Education Student Unit Record Database

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This engineering education research project is the planning stage of constructing a national, longitudinal, student unit-record database that will enable researchers, faculty, administrators and policy makers to understand retention and other metrics that define student pathways through engineering consistently. This award funds the planning of such a database, which builds from a successful prior effort that has led to several insights about student pathways through engineering degree programs. The project will engage a broad array of stakeholders and experts to craft a value proposition for creating and maintaining the proposed database.

The broader significance and importance of this project will be to create resources and networks that can help the United State understand issues in retaining students in engineering degree programs. Research using existing, but small-scale databases, has shown that engineering students from different groups may take follow different trajectories in obtaining an engineering degree or leave degree program for different reasons. The proposed project will extend our understanding of these issues. This project overlaps with NSF's strategic goals of transforming the frontiers through preparation of an engineering workforce with new capabilities and expertise. Additionally NSF's goal of innovating for society is enabled by creating results and research that are useful for society by informing educational policy and practices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Faculty, staff, and administrators provided input to the design of a national database to store student academic records for a 20-year period at a large number of institutions. Student data will be protected by using an identifier that tracks a student over time, but that cannot be linked to an individual student except at the student’s original institution. Institutions are protected through two carefully crafted legally binding data use agreements. A “Restricted Data Use Agreement for Research” allows any authorized researcher full access to study the data, but restricts the researcher from identifying any specific institution in their findings. A “Restricted Data Use Agreement for Institutional Analysis” has allows researchers to identify institutions in their reports, but those reports can only be generated at institutions contributing data to the dataset and the findings from those reports cannot be released beyond the institutions where they are conducted.

This new data partnership has already found favor with multiple institutions. The legal document has been signed by one institution, another has completed a review of the documents and they are being signed, and they are being reviewed by institution’s legal officers at a third. More importantly, 22 additional institutions have provided letters of support that promise to release extraordinary amounts of data for study by the engineering education research community. Those institutions will participate if startup money can be identified to cover the cost of retrieving archival data going back 20 years. The commitment from these institutions acknowledges the potential impact of this database and for research and for improving education.
